Mosques are auspicious in Muslim societies where congregations 26 held five times a day. Public and clergy perceive closing of mosques as a bad omen or anti-27 religious bias, and view the pandemic as a sign of God's rage that can only be appeased by 28 collective prayers. However, when places of worship could potentially aid in the spread of 29 virus the clergy needs to rethink about congregations and convince public to keep the faith, 30 not the germs. While in Pakistan, clergy opposed restrictions on mosques and pressurized 31 government through religious card. As a result, Pakistan-under lockdowns-banned public 32 gatherings excluding congregations in mosques. [5] It defies the logic of social distancing and 33 will whip off all the previous efforts to contain local transmission and would lead to an 34 indomitable public health risk.
